issues.description: The constructor signature of PersonResource differs between the template and the solution. The template defines a single-argument constructor PersonResource(PersonService personService) (lines 23-25 in the template file), while the solution provides a two-argument constructor PersonResource(PersonService personService, String apiKey) (lines 23-25 in the solution file). The problem statement describes a Web Layer containing PersonResource but does not mention any apiKey or additional constructor parameter. This mismatch may confuse students when comparing template and reference solution (they may wonder where the extra String parameter comes from) and could cause unexpected dependency injection problems if an additional String bean/property is not provided. Because the extra parameter is unused in the solution, it is likely unintentional.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the constructor signatures consistent. Either remove the unused String apiKey parameter from the solution's PersonResource constructor so it matches the template (preferred), or add the same parameter to the template and provide a clear, documented injection/source for it (e.g., annotate with @Value("${some.property}") or register a bean). Removing the extra parameter from the solution prevents confusion and avoids requiring an unrelated String dependency.

issues.description: Constructor parameter mismatch for PersonResource: the template's PersonResource has a single-argument constructor (PersonService personService) while the solution's PersonResource constructor adds an extra parameter (String apiKey). The problem statement describes the Web Layer containing PersonResource but does not mention any apiKey. This discrepancy can confuse students when mapping the described PersonResource and the template to the solution (different constructor signatures and an unexplained parameter), and may also create dependency-injection or compilation surprises if students compare implementations or rely on the solution for reference.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the PersonResource constructors consistent across template and solution. Remove the extraneous String apiKey parameter from the solution constructor (i.e., use public PersonResource(PersonService personService) { this.personService = personService; }) OR, if an apiKey is required intentionally, document it in the problem statement and add a matching constructor/configuration in the template (e.g., inject via @Value into a field) so students see the same signature and intent in all artifacts.
